metadata.notes: Updated pilot scope includes explicit ISO 5459 and ISO 1302 plus explicit ISO 2768-1/-2 and ISO 965-1 lane; new ref_ids proposed for missing standards: REF-GPS-6 (ISO 5459) and REF-GPS-7 (ISO 1302). Key freshness findings: ISO 2768-2 is withdrawn and ISO 22081 cancels/replaces it; ISO 965-1 revision is under publication; Machinery Directive 2006/42/EC is replaced by Regulation (EU) 2023/1230 applying from 20 Jan 2027.

references_patch.title: ISO 9409-1:2004 — Manipulating industrial robots — Mechanical interfaces — Part 1: Plates
references_patch.notes: ISO standard defining mechanical interface plate requirements to enable interchangeability between robot manipulators and end-effectors.

references_patch.title: ISO 286 (series) — ISO code system for tolerances on linear sizes (limits & fits; used for H7/m6-style fit designations)
references_patch.notes: Series provides the code system for tolerances and deviations (Part 1) and tables of standard tolerance classes/limit deviations for holes and shafts (Part 2).

references_patch.title: ISO 2768 (general tolerances) — drawing notation ISO 2768-mK (ISO 2768-1 class m + ISO 2768-2 class K; legacy because ISO 2768-2 is withdrawn)
references_patch.notes: ISO 2768-1 defines general tolerances for linear and angular dimensions (classes f/m/c/v). ISO 2768-2 (geometrical tolerances) is withdrawn and is replaced by ISO 22081 for general geometrical/size specifications, so legacy notes like 'mK' need careful referencing.

references_patch.title: ISO 7599:2018 — Anodizing of aluminium and its alloys — Method for specifying decorative and protective anodic oxidation coatings on aluminium
references_patch.notes: Defines how to specify decorative/protective anodic oxidation coatings, characteristic properties, referenced test methods, and minimum performance requirements.

references_patch.title: ISO 228-1:2000 — Pipe threads where pressure-tight joints are not made on the threads — Dimensions, tolerances and designation
references_patch.notes: Defines dimensions/tolerances and designation for 'G' (parallel) pipe threads intended for joints where thread flanks do not provide pressure tightness.

references_patch.title: EN 1672-2:2020 — Food processing machinery — Basic concepts — Part 2: Hygiene and cleanability requirements
references_patch.notes: European standard specifying common hygiene/cleanability requirements for food-processing machinery and components to minimize food-safety risks via hygienic design.

references_patch.title: EN 13870 (current edition includes EN 13870:2015+A1:2021) — Food processing machinery — Portion cutting machines — Safety and hygiene requirements
references_patch.notes: Type-C European standard for portion cutting machines; the DIN listing shows the current document as DIN EN 13870:2022-03 implementing EN 13870:2015+A1:2021 and replacing the 2015 edition.

references_patch.title: EHEDG Guideline 8 (Doc 8) — Hygienic design principles (guidance)
references_patch.notes: EHEDG guidance outlining risk-based hygienic design considerations for entities intended for food manufacturing, emphasizing cleanability and contamination prevention.

references_patch.title: Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 — Food contact materials framework regulation
references_patch.notes: Framework rules for materials/articles intended to come into contact with food; includes general safety (Article 3) and traceability (Article 17). Tooling note: EUR-Lex pages were JS-gated in this session; full-text evidence was taken from the UK legislation mirror.

references_patch.title: Commission Regulation (EU) No 10/2011 — Plastic materials and articles intended to come into contact with food
references_patch.notes: Specific measure for food-contact plastics; includes requirements for written declaration of compliance and supporting documentation (Chapter IV; Articles 15–16; Annex IV). Tooling note: EUR-Lex pages were JS-gated in this session; full-text evidence was taken from the UK legislation mirror (2019-08-29 consolidated text).

references_patch.title: EN 10088-3:2023 — Stainless steels — Part 3: Technical delivery conditions for semi-finished products, bars, rods, wire, sections and bright products of corrosion resistant steels
references_patch.notes: European standard specifying technical delivery conditions for corrosion-resistant (stainless) steels in bar/rod/wire/section forms (DIN listing references EN 10088-3:2023).

references_patch.title: ISO 2768 (general tolerances) — drawing notation ISO 2768-fH (ISO 2768-1 class f + ISO 2768-2 class H; legacy because ISO 2768-2 is withdrawn)
references_patch.notes: Common drawing shorthand combining ISO 2768-1 (linear/angular) with ISO 2768-2 (geometrical, withdrawn). If used, treat as a legacy reference and confirm intended successor approach (e.g., ISO 22081 for general geometrical/size specs).

references_patch.title: Directive 2006/42/EC — Machinery Directive
references_patch.notes: EU machinery safety directive (EHSR in Annex I; manufacturer obligations incl. technical file and instructions). Note: repealed by Regulation (EU) 2023/1230, which applies from 20 Jan 2027; until 19 Jan 2027, the directive remains the applied legal framework per transition schedule. Tooling note: EUR-Lex pages were JS-gated in this session; full-text evidence was taken from the UK legislation mirror; transition note supported by DGUV summary.

references_patch.title: EN ISO 14159 (ISO 14159:2002; EN adoption 2008) — Safety of machinery — Hygiene requirements for the design of machinery
references_patch.notes: Hygiene requirements for machinery design as an EN-adopted ISO standard (DIN listing shows EN ISO 14159:2008 based on ISO 14159:2002).

references_patch.title: VDI 3405 — Additive manufacturing processes — Rapid manufacturing (basics, definitions, processes)
references_patch.notes: VDI guideline covering design, fabrication and assessment of additive-manufactured parts, including quality parameters, testing considerations, and supply-agreement aspects.

references_patch.title: ISO 8015:2011 — Geometrical product specifications (GPS) — Fundamentals — Concepts, principles and rules
references_patch.notes: Defines fundamental GPS concepts/principles/rules used for creating and interpreting geometrical product specifications.

references_patch.title: ISO 1101:2017 — Geometrical product specifications (GPS) — Geometrical tolerancing — Tolerances of form, orientation, location and run-out
references_patch.notes: Defines the symbol language for geometrical tolerancing and the rules for interpreting those specifications.

references_patch.title: ISO 2768-1:1989 — General tolerances — Part 1: Tolerances for linear and angular dimensions without individual tolerance indications
references_patch.notes: Specifies general tolerances for linear/angular dimensions without individual tolerances, in four tolerance classes, to simplify drawing indications.

references_patch.title: ISO 2768-2:1989 — General tolerances — Part 2: Geometrical tolerances for features without individual tolerance indications (withdrawn)
references_patch.notes: ISO catalog indicates ISO 2768-2:1989 is withdrawn; ISO 22081:2021 is stated to cancel/replace it for general geometrical and size specifications.

references_patch.title: ISO 965-1:2013 — ISO general purpose metric screw threads — Tolerances — Part 1: Principles and basic data
references_patch.notes: Provides principles and basic data for thread tolerancing in ISO metric screw thread system; ISO catalog shows a new revision is under publication intended to replace the 2013 edition.

references_patch.title: ISO 5459:2024 — Geometrical product specifications (GPS) — Geometrical tolerancing — Datums and datum systems
references_patch.notes: Specifies terminology, rules and methodology for indicating and understanding datums and datum systems in technical product documentation.

references_patch.title: ISO 1302:2002 — Geometrical product specifications (GPS) — Indication of surface texture in technical product documentation
references_patch.notes: Specifies rules for indicating surface texture in technical product documentation using graphical symbols and textual indications.

top_requirements_paraphrased.requirement_text_paraphrased: If a robot/end-effector connection is specified as ISO 9409-1, the interface geometry (hole pattern, centring features, and associated dimensions) must match the selected ISO 9409-1 interface configuration so tooling remains interchangeable.
Technical product documentation should unambiguously indicate the ISO 9409-1 interface used (e.g., by naming ISO 9409-1 and the intended interface size/type) to avoid mismatched mating plates.

Fits and tolerances for features of size should use the ISO code system of tolerances and deviations (ISO 286-1) so intended clearance/interference fits are consistently interpreted across design, manufacturing, and inspection.

When applying specific fit designations (e.g., H7/m6), the corresponding limit deviations for holes and shafts should be taken from the ISO 286-2 tables and applied to the nominal size ranges used in the design.

If general tolerances are invoked via ISO 2768-1 (e.g., via the drawing notation 'ISO 2768-mK'), unspecified linear and angular dimensions must be interpreted according to the selected tolerance class (m) rather than assumed shop defaults.

Because ISO 2768-2:1989 is withdrawn and ISO 22081:2021 is stated to cancel/replace it, any notation that relies on an ISO 2768-2 class (e.g., '...K') should be treated as legacy and reviewed for how general geometrical tolerancing is intended to be applied.

When anodic oxidation coatings on aluminium are specified per ISO 7599, the specification should identify the coating characteristics and required performance properties rather than leaving coating details ambiguous.

Verification of anodic oxidation coatings should follow the methods of test and minimum performance requirements referenced in ISO 7599 when the coating is a functional requirement (e.g., corrosion resistance, appearance).
If a pipe thread is specified as ISO 228-1, the design must use ISO 228-1 thread form/dimensions/tolerances and the correct designation so suppliers/manufacturers produce matching threaded parts.

Because ISO 228-1 applies to pipe threads where pressure-tight joints are not achieved on the thread flanks, the sealing method (e.g., gasket, O-ring, face seal) should be defined elsewhere in the design/drawing if pressure sealing is needed.

Food processing machinery should be designed and constructed to meet hygiene and cleanability requirements that minimize food-safety risk (contagion/infection/illness/injury risks associated with food) for intended use.

Documentation should capture the hygienic design assumptions needed for correct use and cleaning (e.g., what is intended to be cleanable, and how) so downstream manufacturing and validation are aligned.

If the product is a portion cutting machine within the scope of EN 13870, the design should address the significant hazards and safety/hygiene requirements covered by that type-C standard for intended and reasonably foreseeable misuse conditions.
Project documentation should reference the current EN 13870 edition (DIN entry indicates EN 13870:2015 was replaced by the amended 2022 document implementing EN 13870:2015+A1:2021).

Hygienic design should be treated as a risk-based design objective: product-contact and splash zones should be designed for effective cleaning and to avoid contamination traps, consistent with EHEDG hygienic design guidance.

Claims of hygienic design compliance should be backed by documented rationale (cleaning concept, intended use, validation approach) rather than only informal statements, since EHEDG guidance is implementation-oriented.

Food-contact materials/articles must be manufactured under GMP and must not transfer constituents to food in quantities that could endanger health, cause unacceptable composition change, or deteriorate organoleptic characteristics under normal/foreseeable use.

Business operators must ensure traceability of materials/articles at all stages and maintain systems/procedures enabling identification (to facilitate control, recall, consumer information, and responsibility attribution).

At marketing stages other than retail, plastic food-contact materials/articles and relevant intermediate products must have a written declaration of compliance that includes the annexed information and is renewed when changes affecting compliance occur or when new scientific data becomes available.

Business operators must keep appropriate supporting documentation demonstrating compliance (including conditions/results of testing and detailed substance information) and provide it to competent authorities on request; the declaration content requirements are detailed in Annex IV.

When corrosion-resistant (stainless) steel supply is specified for bars/rods/wire/sections/bright products, technical delivery conditions should align with EN 10088-3 so procurement and inspection criteria are consistent.
Material specifications should include the steel grade and delivery condition details appropriate to product form to avoid under-specification for food-industry use cases.
If general tolerances are invoked via ISO 2768-1 using a fine class (f), unspecified dimensions must be interpreted via the selected class and not treated as unspecified or 'tight by default'.

Because ISO 2768-2:1989 is withdrawn (and ISO 22081:2021 cancels/replaces it), any use of an ISO 2768-2 class (e.g., '...H') should be handled as a legacy reference requiring explicit decision on successor/general GPS approach.

Before placing machinery on the market/putting into service, the manufacturer (or authorised representative) must ensure EHSR compliance, compile/hold the technical file, provide necessary information (incl. instructions), perform conformity assessment, draw up the EC declaration of conformity, and affix CE marking.

All machinery must be accompanied by instructions in the required language(s), with rules for original instructions vs translations and minimum contents addressing intended use and foreseeable misuse.
Machinery intended for hygienic applications should incorporate hygiene requirements into design (materials, surfaces, layout, cleanability) consistent with ISO 14159-based EN adoption.
Documentation should state hygiene-related information needed for safe use and cleaning/maintenance where hygiene is a relevant risk.

Additive manufacturing projects should document the selected AM process and its relevant quality parameters so part assessment and verification are feasible (design/fabrication/assessment considerations).
Supply agreements and part testing expectations should be aligned with documented AM quality parameters to avoid non-verifiable requirements for as-built parts.
Geometrical tolerances on drawings should use the ISO 1101 symbol language and be interpretable by its rules (feature control frames, symbols, and interpretation conventions).
When GD&T is present, it should be complete enough to be unambiguous for verification (e.g., tolerance type/value and applicable datum references where required).
Datums and datum systems used in technical product documentation should be indicated and understood according to ISO 5459 terminology and rules, so datum references in GPS are consistent.
Where a datum system is referenced by a specification (e.g., GD&T), the documentation should define the datum features and their hierarchy/combination clearly to avoid misinterpretation.
GPS specifications should be created and interpreted using the fundamental concepts and rules of ISO 8015 to ensure consistent meaning across referenced GPS standards.
If a drawing deviates from default GPS principles (e.g., by imposing additional relationships beyond the default rules), that deviation should be explicitly documented rather than assumed.
If ISO 2768-1 is referenced for general tolerances, the drawing must indicate the selected tolerance class so default tolerances for unspecified linear and angular dimensions are determinate.

ISO 2768-1 general tolerances are intended to simplify drawing indications for typical manufacturing (metal removal or sheet metal forming); if the manufacturing process is outside that norm, general tolerances should be reviewed for suitability.
ISO 2768-2:1989 is marked withdrawn in the ISO catalog; use of this reference in new documentation should be consciously justified (legacy support) or migrated to the successor approach.

ISO 22081:2021 states it cancels and replaces ISO 2768-2:1989; if general geometrical tolerancing without individual indications is desired, the project should decide whether to adopt ISO 22081 (or otherwise explicitly freeze to ISO 2768-2:1989).

Surface texture requirements in technical product documentation should be expressed using ISO 1302 graphical symbols and textual indications so surface requirements are unambiguous and machine-readable.

If surface texture is critical to function, the indication should provide the necessary parameters (e.g., roughness parameter and value, and any additional qualifiers) rather than using incomplete symbols.
Metric screw thread tolerancing should follow ISO 965-1 principles and basic data so thread tolerance classes/positions on drawings map to a consistent interpretation for manufacture and gaging.

ISO catalog indicates a revision of ISO 965-1 is under publication and intended to replace the 2013 edition; projects relying on detailed mappings should monitor and update references when the new edition is published.

rule_candidates.title: ISO 9409-1 robot interface geometry must match selected flange pattern
rule_candidates.description: Verifies that an ISO 9409-1 robot mechanical interface is implemented with the correct hole pattern and locating features for interchangeability.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Compute bolt pattern + locating features and compare against the selected ISO 9409-1 interface variant library (size/type).

rule_candidates.fix_template: Select a valid ISO 9409-1 interface size/type and regenerate the flange geometry to match; update the mating plate accordingly.

rule_candidates.title: Robot/end-effector drawings must reference ISO 9409-1 when that interface is used
rule_candidates.description: Ensures the drawing references ISO 9409-1 to avoid supplier ambiguity for robot flange interfaces.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Extract title block and interface callouts; flag if ISO 9409-1 is missing.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Add a note/callout referencing ISO 9409-1 and include the intended interface designation (size/type).

rule_candidates.title: Fit-critical mating holes/shafts must have an ISO 286 fit designation
rule_candidates.description: Checks that fit-critical mating features are annotated with ISO 286 tolerance classes (e.g., H7/h6) rather than relying only on general tolerances.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Requires upstream tagging of fit-critical mating pairs; if unavailable, treat as evidence_gap and request tagging.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Add ISO 286 fit callouts for each fit-critical pair (hole and shaft) and confirm nominal size range matches the ISO tables.

rule_candidates.title: Computed ISO 286 fit outcome must match the intended fit type
rule_candidates.description: Validates that the selected ISO 286 tolerance classes produce the intended clearance/transition/interference range for each tagged mating pair.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: For each tagged mating pair, compute min/max clearance from ISO 286-derived limit deviations and compare against intended fit type configured by the designer.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Adjust tolerance classes or nominal sizes (e.g., change from m6 to k6) until min/max clearance meets the intended functional fit; update drawing callouts.

rule_candidates.title: General tolerance note must be present when ISO 2768-mK is used
rule_candidates.description: Ensures the drawing explicitly states the default general tolerance class ISO 2768-mK so suppliers do not apply unspecified shop defaults.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Also recommend explicitly dating any ISO 2768-2 reference component because ISO 2768-2 is withdrawn; treat undated references as needing manual review.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Add to title block: 'General tolerances ISO 2768-mK' (and, if referencing ISO 2768-2, add ':1989' or adopt ISO 22081 explicitly).

rule_candidates.title: Anodizing callouts must reference ISO 7599 when anodic oxidation is specified
rule_candidates.description: If anodizing is specified as a controlled surface treatment, the drawing should reference ISO 7599 and state the required coating attributes (e.g., grade/thickness/performance).

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Parse surface treatment notes; if anodizing is present but ISO 7599 is absent, raise evidence gap.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Update the surface treatment callout to include ISO 7599 and key coating properties required for the application; align with supplier capability.

rule_candidates.title: Pipe thread callouts must explicitly state ISO 228-1 for G-threads
rule_candidates.description: Ensures pipe threads intended as ISO 228-1 are called out as ISO 228-1 to avoid confusion with pressure-tight thread standards.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Also verify that the thread designation uses 'G' for ISO 228-1 parallel pipe threads.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Revise pipe thread notes to include 'ISO 228-1' and the proper designation (e.g., 'G 1/2'). Specify sealing method elsewhere if joint must be pressure tight.

rule_candidates.title: ISO 228-1 pipe threads must be parallel and match designated size
rule_candidates.description: Checks that modeled ISO 228-1 pipe threads are parallel (not tapered) and match the designated nominal size for manufacturability and assembly interchangeability.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Detect and classify pipe threads; for ISO 228-1, verify parallel geometry and nominal designation against the selected size.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Replace tapered threads with ISO 228-1 parallel geometry (or change the callout standard) and confirm the mating component uses the same designation.

rule_candidates.title: Food-contact designs must not include enclosed/trapped volumes in product/splash zones
rule_candidates.description: Flags enclosed cavities or trapped volumes in product-contact or splash zones that are difficult to clean, supporting EN 1672-2 hygienic/cleanability intent.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Use computational geometry to detect enclosed voids and non-drainable pockets in tagged hygienic zones; require zone tagging if absent.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Eliminate enclosed cavities in hygienic zones (open, vent, drain, or redesign); if a cavity is necessary, document cleaning/inspection access and validation.

rule_candidates.title: Food machinery drawings must state hygiene/cleanability assumptions needed for correct use
rule_candidates.description: Ensures the drawing pack or associated documentation states hygienic zoning and intended cleaning method so manufacturing and verification are aligned.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Accept either explicit zone marking on drawings or a linked hygiene zoning document referenced in drawing notes/BOM.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Add hygiene zoning (product-contact/splash/non-contact) and intended cleaning method reference to the drawing notes or linked spec; align with EN 1672-2 compliance rationale.

rule_candidates.title: If the product is a portion cutting machine, documentation must reference EN 13870
rule_candidates.description: EN 13870 is a type-C standard for portion cutting machines; if applicable, ensure the documentation references EN 13870 and uses the current edition.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Apply only when project.product_category indicates a portion cutting machine (or equivalent). If not applicable, suppress.

rule_candidates.fix_template: If applicable, add 'EN 13870:2015+A1:2021' (or local adoption) to the standards list in the drawing pack and align risk assessment accordingly.

rule_candidates.title: Hygienic designs should avoid non-drainable pockets and inaccessible crevices in hygienic zones
rule_candidates.description: Checks for trapped volumes and inaccessible crevices in hygienic zones as a proxy for EHEDG hygienic design guidance.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Compute trapped volume / dead-pocket metrics in tagged hygienic zones (product-contact and splash). If hygienic zones are not tagged, raise evidence_gap first.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Redesign pockets/crevices to be drainable and cleanable (e.g., add drainage, open access, or redesign geometry). Document any unavoidable non-drainable features and their validated cleaning method.

rule_candidates.title: Food equipment docs should reference EHEDG hygienic design guidance when claimed
rule_candidates.description: If hygienic design compliance is claimed or required, the documentation should reference the applied guidance (e.g., EHEDG Doc 8) and link to the design rationale/validation evidence.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Accept either explicit 'EHEDG' reference in drawing notes or a linked hygiene specification document referenced by the drawing pack.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Add a note in the drawing pack naming EHEDG Guideline 8 (Doc 8) as applied guidance and link to the hygienic design rationale/cleanability validation report.

rule_candidates.title: Food-contact materials must have framework FCM compliance evidence and traceability controls
rule_candidates.description: Requires evidence that food-contact materials/articles are compliant with EU 1935/2004 general safety requirements and that traceability systems exist for recall and responsibility attribution.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Check for a stored compliance statement or supplier declaration tying the part/material to EU 1935/2004; separately confirm traceability (batch/lot linkage).

rule_candidates.fix_template: Obtain and attach supplier/manufacturer documentation supporting EU 1935/2004 compliance and implement lot/batch traceability in ERP/QMS; add references in the technical file.

rule_candidates.title: Food-contact plastics must have EU 10/2011 declaration of compliance and supporting documentation
rule_candidates.description: Requires a written declaration of compliance and supporting documentation for plastic food-contact materials/articles and relevant intermediate products when EU 10/2011 applies.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Verify presence of DoC and that it includes Annex IV information; verify supporting test/risk documentation is stored and retrievable for authorities.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Collect the EU 10/2011 Declaration of Compliance (with Annex IV fields) and store supporting migration/testing documentation; update supplier requirements if missing.

rule_candidates.title: Stainless steel material specs must be stated per EN 10088-3 where applicable
rule_candidates.description: Ensures stainless steel bars/rods/wire/sections used for parts are specified with an EN 10088-3-compliant grade/delivery condition in the drawing/BOM so procurement and inspection are consistent.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: If the project uses stainless steels in the EN 10088-3 product forms, require explicit EN 10088-3 referencing and grade identification; otherwise suppress.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Update the BOM/material callout to include EN 10088-3 (or appropriate EN 10088 part for the product form) and specify the required steel grade/delivery condition.

rule_candidates.title: General tolerance note must be present when ISO 2768-fH is used
rule_candidates.description: Ensures the drawing explicitly states ISO 2768-fH as the default general tolerance class for unspecified dimensions, to avoid uncontrolled tolerance assumptions.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Also recommend explicitly dating any ISO 2768-2 reference component because ISO 2768-2 is withdrawn; treat use of geometrical class (H) as legacy unless matched to a successor approach.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Add to title block: 'General tolerances ISO 2768-fH' (and, if referencing ISO 2768-2, add ':1989' or adopt ISO 22081 explicitly).

rule_candidates.title: Machinery Directive technical file and EC declaration must exist for CE-marked machinery
rule_candidates.description: Requires evidence that the technical file, instructions, and EC declaration of conformity exist when Machinery Directive conformity is claimed.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Confirm Article 5 obligations are met via document presence and version control; treat missing documents as critical evidence gaps.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Create/collect the EC Declaration of Conformity, technical file (incl. risk assessment), and instructions; store them under revision control and reference applied standards.

rule_candidates.title: Hygienic-zone geometry must minimize crevices and inaccessible joints
rule_candidates.description: Checks for narrow gaps/crevices and inaccessible joints in hygienic zones as a proxy for meeting ISO 14159 hygienic design intent.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Detect gaps below a configurable threshold and inaccessible joints in tagged hygienic zones; require zone tagging if absent.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Redesign joints to eliminate crevices (e.g., continuous/sealed welds, hygienic fasteners, open access) and ensure surfaces are accessible for cleaning/inspection.

rule_candidates.title: Hygienic machinery documentation must include cleaning/maintenance information
rule_candidates.description: Ensures drawing pack or linked docs include the cleaning/maintenance information necessary to support hygienic use when ISO 14159 is in scope.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Accept either explicit cleaning instructions in the drawing pack or a referenced cleaning procedure document ID.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Add cleaning/maintenance instructions reference (document ID) to the drawing pack and ensure it is controlled and accessible to users.

rule_candidates.title: Additive manufacturing drawings must document AM process and key quality parameters when VDI 3405 is applied
rule_candidates.description: If a part is produced by additive manufacturing, ensure the drawing/spec includes process identification and quality parameters (as-built expectations) so inspection and acceptance are feasible.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Apply when project.manufacturing.process == 'additive'; otherwise suppress. If VDI 3405 is the governing guideline, require reference and parameter list (at least as a linked spec).

rule_candidates.fix_template: Add 'VDI 3405' reference and link to the AM process parameter sheet (process type, layer parameters, post-processing, inspection method) in the drawing pack.

rule_candidates.title: GD&T feature control frames must be syntactically complete per ISO 1101
rule_candidates.description: Flags incomplete or non-parsable GD&T feature control frames (missing tolerance value, missing datum references where required, malformed symbols).

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Implement a parser for ISO 1101-like feature control frames; treat unrecognized patterns as invalid.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Fix malformed GD&T callouts so each frame includes the required ISO 1101 fields (symbol, tolerance value, and required datum references/modifiers).

rule_candidates.title: Datum references used in GD&T must be defined per ISO 5459
rule_candidates.description: Ensures every datum identifier referenced by a GD&T callout is associated with a defined datum feature and datum system.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Extract datum symbols and datum feature identifiers, then cross-check every datum letter used in feature control frames is defined somewhere on the drawing.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Define missing datum features/datum system on the drawing (datum feature symbol + leader) so every referenced datum is unambiguous.

rule_candidates.title: GPS drawings should reference ISO 8015 when ISO GPS rules are intended to apply
rule_candidates.description: A lightweight check that the drawing pack references ISO 8015 so GPS default concepts/rules are explicit.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Look for ISO 8015 in title block standards list or general notes.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Add 'ISO 8015' to the drawing standards list if ISO GPS principles are intended to apply across the drawing.

rule_candidates.title: If general tolerances are used, the drawing must reference ISO 2768-1 and the tolerance class
rule_candidates.description: Ensures explicit ISO 2768-1 reference and tolerance class (f/m/c/v) for general linear/angular tolerances when individual tolerances are not fully specified.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Check that the general tolerance note includes ISO 2768-1 and a class identifier; if only 'ISO 2768' is used, treat as ambiguous and raise evidence gap.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Update the general tolerance note to include ISO 2768-1 and the selected class (e.g., 'ISO 2768-1 m'). If also using geometrical general tolerances, explicitly decide how to handle ISO 2768-2 withdrawal.

rule_candidates.title: If ISO 2768-2 is referenced, it must be explicitly dated or migrated because ISO 2768-2 is withdrawn
rule_candidates.description: ISO 2768-2:1989 is withdrawn; this rule flags ambiguous or undated references to ISO 2768-2 in drawings and requires an explicit decision (freeze to :1989 or adopt a successor approach).

check_logic.evaluator_hint: If ISO 2768-2 appears without an edition (e.g., ':1989'), raise evidence gap and recommend explicitly freezing the reference or adopting ISO 22081.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Replace 'ISO 2768-2' with 'ISO 2768-2:1989' if legacy use is intended, or update the general GPS approach (e.g., adopt ISO 22081) and revise drawing notes accordingly.

rule_candidates.title: Surface texture indications must include parameter/value per ISO 1302 when used
rule_candidates.description: Flags surface texture symbols/callouts missing the required parameter/value information, to keep surface finish requirements unambiguous.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Parse ISO 1302-like surface texture symbols and ensure required fields (at least one parameter/value) exist for each callout.

rule_candidates.fix_template: Complete each surface texture callout with the required parameter/value (e.g., Ra value) and any needed qualifiers/modifiers following ISO 1302 conventions.

rule_candidates.title: Metric thread callouts must include tolerance class/position when ISO 965-1 is applied
rule_candidates.description: Ensures metric thread specifications include tolerance class/position (e.g., internal 6H, external 6g) so manufacturing and gaging are unambiguous.

check_logic.evaluator_hint: Parse metric thread callouts (e.g., 'M10x1') and verify presence of ISO 965-style tolerance class (e.g., '6H', '6g').

rule_candidates.fix_template: Update thread callouts to include tolerance class (e.g., 'M10x1-6H' internal, 'M10x1-6g' external) consistent with ISO 965-1 and the intended fit/function.

gaps_and_unknowns.impact: ISO 2768-2 is withdrawn; drawings that reference ISO 2768-2 (or shorthand classes K/H via 'mK'/'fH') can create ambiguity and potential contractual risk if the intended general geometrical tolerancing approach is not explicitly frozen or migrated.
gaps_and_unknowns.recommended_action: Decide a policy: (a) freeze legacy references by explicitly dating 'ISO 2768-2:1989' where used, or (b) add ISO 22081 to the references/rule library and migrate general geometrical/size specifications accordingly; update drawing templates.

gaps_and_unknowns.impact: ISO 2768-mK is a common drawing shorthand, not a standalone ISO publication; automated checks need a mapping to ISO 2768-1 tolerance class 'm' and a decided successor approach for the geometrical component previously covered by ISO 2768-2 class 'K'.
gaps_and_unknowns.recommended_action: Implement explicit parsing of 'ISO 2768-mK' into (ISO 2768-1 class m) + (legacy ISO 2768-2 class K). Require an explicit project-level choice for the general geometrical tolerancing regime (legacy vs updated).

gaps_and_unknowns.impact: ISO 2768-fH depends on legacy ISO 2768-2 (withdrawn); automated tolerance enforcement for 'H' requires a legacy table and/or a migration strategy.
gaps_and_unknowns.recommended_action: Same as for ISO 2768-mK: parse into ISO 2768-1 class f plus a legacy/general geometrical tolerancing policy; require explicit dating if ISO 2768-2 is retained.

gaps_and_unknowns.impact: EU 10/2011 is frequently amended; the evidence source used here is a 2019 consolidated text mirror, so recent changes (e.g., 2025 amendments) may not be reflected in the derived rule candidates.
gaps_and_unknowns.recommended_action: In implementation, fetch and pin the currently applicable consolidated text from EUR-Lex (ELI) and update rule extraction for Article/Annex changes, especially DoC content, purity definitions, recycled plastic provisions, and documentation requirements.

gaps_and_unknowns.impact: The Machinery Directive 2006/42/EC is being replaced by Regulation (EU) 2023/1230 with application from 20 Jan 2027; compliance overlays must handle the transitional period and avoid hardcoding outdated legal regimes.
gaps_and_unknowns.recommended_action: Add a date-aware legal applicability switch: until 19 Jan 2027, use 2006/42/EC rules; from 20 Jan 2027, migrate to Regulation (EU) 2023/1230 and update documentation requirements accordingly.

gaps_and_unknowns.impact: EHEDG Doc 8 is guidance and often distributed via membership/purchase; clause-level extraction and numeric thresholds (e.g., surface finish recommendations) are not reliably available from the public summary page.
gaps_and_unknowns.recommended_action: Obtain the official EHEDG Doc 8 publication for clause-level/numeric extraction, or keep rules as 'evidence gaps' requiring manual hygienic validation reports rather than enforcing numeric thresholds.

gaps_and_unknowns.impact: EN 13870 is a type-C standard applicable to portion cutting machines; applying it to unrelated food machinery could produce false positives.
gaps_and_unknowns.recommended_action: Gate EN 13870 rules behind a product taxonomy flag (e.g., project.product_category == portion_cutting_machine).

gaps_and_unknowns.impact: ISO 965-1 is under publication for a new revision; tolerance mapping or callout validation logic may change when the new edition is published.
gaps_and_unknowns.recommended_action: Monitor ISO publication status; when the new ISO 965-1 is released, update thread callout parsing rules and any tolerance lookup tables accordingly.

gaps_and_unknowns.impact: EN 1672-2 is paywalled; detailed clause-level requirements (and any numeric design criteria) cannot be fully extracted from public metadata alone, limiting deterministic rule precision.
gaps_and_unknowns.recommended_action: Acquire the full EN 1672-2 text for clause mapping; until then, treat geometry checks as heuristic/hybrid and emphasize evidence artifacts (hygiene zoning, cleanability validation).
